request."}]}],"floats":[],"footnotes":[],"attachments":[]},"crossMark":{"isOpen":false},"domainConfig":{"assetRoute":"https://sdfestaticassets-eu-west-1.sciencedirectassets.com/prod/fa1c8b2301a14e2a58982c67ebe341e7af7fd8fc","cdnAssetsHost":"https://sdfestaticassets-eu-west-1.sciencedirectassets.com"},"downloadIssue":{"openOnPageLoad":false,"isOpen":false,"downloadCapOpen":false,"articles":[],"selected":[]},"enrichedContent":{"tableOfContents":false,"researchData":{"hasResearchData":false,"dataProfile":{},"openData":{},"mendeleyData":{},"databaseLinking":{}},"geospatialData":{"attachments":[]},"interactiveCaseInsights":{},"virtualMicroscope":{}},"entitledRecommendations":{"openOnPageLoad":false,"isOpen":false,"articles":[],"selected":[],"currentPage":1,"totalPages":1},"exam":{},"helpText":{"keyDates":{"html":"<div class=\"key-dates-help\"><h3 class=\"u-margin-s-bottom u-h4\">Publication milestones</h3><p class=\"u-margin-m-bottom\">The dates displayed for an article provide information on when various publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. View our <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/researcher/author/submit-your-paper\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing with Elsevier: step-by-step</span></span></a> page to learn more about the publishing process. For any questions on your own submission or other questions related to publishing an article, <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://service.elsevier.com/app/phone/supporthub/publishing\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">contact our Researcher support team.</span></span></a></p></div>","title":"What do these dates mean?"}},"glossary":{},"issueNavigation":{"previous":{},"next":{}},"linkingHubLinks":{},"metrics":{"metricGroup":{"citations":[],"captures":[],"mentions":[],"socialMedia":[]},"isLoading":false,"error":false,"hasMetrics":false},"preview":{},"rawtext":"","recommendations":{},"references":{},"referenceLinks":{"internal":[],"internalLoaded":false,"external":[]},"refersTo":{},"referredToBy":{},"relatedContent":{"isModal":false,"isOpenSpecialIssueArticles":false,"isOpenVirtualSpecialIssueLink":false,"isOpenRecommendations":true,"isOpenSubstances":true,"citingArticles":[false,false,false,false,false,false],"recommendations":[false,false,false,false,false,false]},"seamlessAccess":{},"specialIssueArticles":{},"substances":{},"supplementaryFilesData":[],"tableOfContents":{"showEntitledTocLinks":true},"tail":{},"transientError":{"isOpen":false},"sidePanel":{"openState":1},"viewConfig":{"articleFeature":{"aiNavigation":true},"pathPrefix":""},"virtualSpecialIssue":{"showVirtualSpecialIssueLink":false},"usageProps":{"itemStage":"S300","isAip":false,"tombAip":"0","sample":false},"userCookiePreferences":{"STRICTLY_NECESSARY":true,"PERFORMANCE":true,"FUNCTIONAL":true,"TARGETING":false}};

object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ensm.2024.103925</span><svg class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="abs0001"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abss0001"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara009"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0001">A sol-gel synthetic route was developed to produce cost-effective Alluaudite-Type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes from anhydrous Stanfieldite-Type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor, avoiding potential damage from crystal water.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0002">The distinct physio-electrochemical properties of Stanfieldite-Type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Alluaudite-Type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> were elucidated through experimental analysis and DFT calculations.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0003">For all-climate condition tests at −25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite cathodes sustained over 90 % capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 c or exceeded 95 % after 200 cycles at 2 C.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="abs0002"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abss0002"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara010">Low-cost and long-life cathode materials, such as the polyanionic iron-based Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, are crucial for future large-scale energy storage applications. This material is typically synthesized from the hydrated precursor Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O. However, the vapor released during the heating of crystal water can lead to reduced crystallinity, increased fraction of Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities, and potential structural damage to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. For the first time, we synthesized a stable Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> material using a well-designed sol-gel method. This approach effectively mitigates the aforementioned risks by facilitating a unique transition from anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode. The enhanced crystallinity, controllable impurity fraction, and reduced migration barriers of the pristine Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode significantly improve electrochemical performance. Moreover, we constructed Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite cathodes to optimize their high-rate capacity and cycling retention. At 25 °C, these composites exhibit remarkable high-rate capacity and maintain an impressive 92.2 % capacity retention after 1000 cycles at 10 C. In tests under extreme conditions at −25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, they sustained over 90 % capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 C or exceeded 95 % after 200 cycles at 2 C. Furthermore, the assembled Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C//HC full cells demonstrate superior rate capacity and long-term cycling stability, indicating their promising potential for commercial applications.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="abs0003"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="abss0003"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara011"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0008"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-ga1.jpg" height="197" alt="Image, graphical abstract"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (260KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (260KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span>A sol-gel synthetic route was developed to produce cost-effective Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes from anhydrous Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor, avoiding potential damage from crystal water. The distinct physio-electrochemical properties of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> were elucidated through experimental analysis and DFT calculations. For all-climate condition tests at -25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite cathodes sustained over 90 % capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 C or exceeded 95 % after 200 cycles at 2 C.</div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829724007682"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829724007529"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="keys0001" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="key0001" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0002">Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub></span></div><div id="key0002" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0003">Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub></span></div><div id="key0001a" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0002a">All-climate condition</span></div><div id="key0003" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0004">Iron-based polyanion</span></div><div id="key0004" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0005">Sodium-ion batteries</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0006" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0005">The escalating environmental degradation attributed to conventional fossil fuels has underscored the imperative for investigating and cultivating sustainable, renewable, and clean energy alternatives [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0001" name="bbib0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a>]. Given the sporadic and disparate distribution of these renewable resources, the establishment of large-scale energy storage systems capable of judiciously harnessing and distributing energy emerges as a direct and efficacious solution [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0002" name="bbib0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a>]. Lithium-ion batteries, with their outstanding cycling life and moderate energy density, are widely adopted in industrial fields as large-scale energy storage containers [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0003" name="bbib0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>]. However, their subpar safety under high temperatures and poorer electrochemical performance at low temperatures are concerning [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0004" name="bbib0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0005" name="bbib0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>], especially in extreme application scenarios such as photovoltaic installations in deserts and wind power installations at high altitudes. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), with a similar energy storage mechanism to lithium-ion batteries, are viewed as potent contenders in the future large-scale energy storage market due to their earth-abundant elements, superior thermal safety and low-temperature electrochemical performance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0006" name="bbib0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">6</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0007" name="bbib0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">7</span></span></a>]. Consequently, the development of cost-effective, long-lasting cathodes for sodium-ion batteries that are suitable for large-scale energy storage applications in all-climate conditions, has captured researchers' attention. In this context, polyanionic iron-based cathode materials are recognized as one of the most promising candidates, attributed to their low cost, wide temperature stability and robust cycling performance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0008" name="bbib0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0009" name="bbib0009" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0009"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0010" name="bbib0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0006">Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> is recognized as an excellent cathode material due to its high operating voltage and moderate capacity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0011" name="bbib0011" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0011"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0012" name="bbib0012" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0012"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>]. However, its polyanionic framework leads to poor electronic conductivity and sluggish reaction kinetics [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0014" name="bbib0014" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0014"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0015" name="bbib0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>]. To mitigate the significant decomposition of SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> groups above 450 °C, researchers have employed both solid-state [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0016" name="bbib0016" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0016"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0017" name="bbib0017" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0017"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>] and aqueous-solution synthetic routes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0019" name="bbib0019" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0019"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>], incorporating ex-situ conductive materials with the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes to improve electrochemical performance. In aqueous-solution routes, the hydrated precursor Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O is typically used to produce Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0020" name="bbib0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>]. However, the vapor released from the heated crystal water may compromise the crystal integrity of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, potentially reverting it back to Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O through hydration reactions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>]. Additionally, the anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor cannot be directly obtained by sintering hydrated Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O material, leading to a product containing Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0022" name="bbib0022" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0022"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a>]. Some efforts have been made to synthesize the anhydrous precursor Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> by replicating the synthetic conditions used for Na<sub>2</sub>Co(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Na<sub>2</sub>Ni(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0023" name="bbib0023" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0023"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>]. Unfortunately, researchers have only succeeded in obtaining the stable Vanthoffite-type Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0023" name="bbib0023" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0023"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0025" name="bbib0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>]. Consequently, the physicochemical properties of a stable Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and the crystallographic transition mechanism from anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode have not yet been systematically reported.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0007">In this study, a stable Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> materials were synthesized for the first time. The potential risks of low crystallinity, structural damage, and irreversible formation of more Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities due to crystal water vapor were mitigated through the unique transition from anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor to Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode. Compared to electrochemically inactive Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, the pristine Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> exhibits enhanced low-rate capacity but demonstrates suboptimal performance in high-rate capacity and cycle retention. To address these limitations, we constructed the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite cathodes with improved conductivity, which exhibited a higher average working potential, superior high-rate capacity, and an excellent capacity retention. In tests under various climatic conditions at −25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, the composite cathodes maintained over 90 % capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 C or over 95 % after 200 cycles at 2 C. Furthermore, the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C//HC full cells, which were assembled with hard carbon (HC) as the anode and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C as the cathode, exhibited exceptional rate capacity and enhanced cycling stability.</div></section><section id="sec0002"><h2 id="cesectitle0007" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0008"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>a</strong> illustrates our carefully designed sol-gel synthesis pathway, specifically aimed at mitigating the deleterious effects of moisture on the Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, thus marking a significant departure from the traditional direct sintering methods. For comparison, we prepared the conventional hydrated Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O precursor and tried to obtain the related product Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H through a one-step calcination process (<strong>Figure S1</strong>). Notably, we observed that water droplets, which condensed from the water vapor, continued to form on the inner surface of the tube wall even as the temperature rose to approximately 270 °C during calcination (<strong>Figure S2</strong>). X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis delineates the distinct crystal structures of the Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>​Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>​)<sub>2</sub>​ and the Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. Comprehensive powder XRD Rietveld refinement data confirm that the crystal structure of the Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> phase is analogous to that of Na<sub>2</sub>Co(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (PDF#97–019–4629) and Na<sub>2</sub>Ni(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (PDF#97–019–4630) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0026" name="bbib0026" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0026"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>], while diverging from the derived phases Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H, and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 1</span></span></a><strong>b</strong>-<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a><strong>c, Figures S3-S4</strong>)[<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0027" name="bbib0027" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0027"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>]. A juxtaposition of the principal crystallographic data for Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H, and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C is delineated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl0001" name="btbl0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a> and <strong>Tables S1-S5.</strong> The Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> exhibits larger lattice parameters with <em>a</em> = 23.37554 Å, <em>c</em> = 17.46092 Å, and <em>V</em> = 4155.171 Å<sup>3</sup> compared to pristine Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. However, it has smaller lattice parameters of <em>b</em> = 10.31535 Å Notably, all principal crystallographic parameters of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H are smaller than those of pristine Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and modified Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C, indicating potential structural damage (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl0001" name="btbl0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a>).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0001"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr1.jpg" height="997" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0001"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0001"><p id="spara001"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. <strong>Synthetic routes and crystallographic structure of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>:</strong> (<strong>a</strong>) Schematic diagram of synthetic routes. (<strong>b</strong>) Powder XRD Rietveld refinement pattern of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>. The experimental profiles, calculated data, the difference, and the theoretical Bragg positions are represented by black circles, blue lines, orange lines, and solid ticks, respectively. (<strong>c</strong>) The crystallographic structure of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> is projected along the [100] direction, (<strong>d</strong>) the [010] direction, (<strong>e</strong>) the [001] direction, (<strong>f</strong>) three crystallographic site of Fe sites, and (<strong>g</strong>) local environment of seven independent Na sites. Gold spheres, yellow tetrahedra, and green octahedra represent Na<sup>+</sup>, SO<sub>4</sub>, and FeO<sub>6</sub>, respectively. One FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedron shares an edge with one adjacent SO<sub>4</sub> tetrahedron to constitute a FeSO<sub>8</sub> dimer. (<strong>h</strong>) Powder XRD Rietveld refinement pattern of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. The experimental profiles, calculated data, the difference, and the theoretical Bragg positions are represented by black circles, red lines, orange lines, and solid ticks, respectively. (<strong>i</strong>) The crystallographic structure of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> is projected along the [100] direction, (<strong>j</strong>) the [010] direction, (<strong>k</strong>) the [001] direction, (<strong>l</strong>) local environment of Fe sites, and (<strong>m</strong>) three independent Na sites. Green octahedra, yellow tetrahedra, and gold spheres represent FeO<sub>6</sub>, SO<sub>4</sub>, and Na, respectively. One FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedron shares an edge with another adjacent FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedron to constitute a Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>10</sub> dimer.</p></span></span></figure><div class="tables rowsep-0 colsep-0 frame-topbot" id="tbl0001"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0002"><p id="spara008"><span class="label">Table 1</span>. The principal crystallographic data for Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub>,</sub> Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H, and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="rowsep-1"><td scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0001"><span class="screen-reader-only">Empty Cell</span></td><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0002">Structure</th><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0003">a<br>(Å)</th><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0004">b<br>(Å)</th><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0005">c<br>(Å)</th><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0006">V<br>Å[<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0003" name="bbib0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>]</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><th class="align-left valign-top" id="en0007" scope="row"><strong>Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub></strong></th><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0008">Stanfieldite</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0009">23.37554</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0010">10.31535</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0011">17.46092</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0012">4155.171</td></tr><tr><th class="align-left valign-top" id="en0013" scope="row"><strong>Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub></strong></th><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0014">Alluaudite</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0015">12.65514</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0016">12.77267</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0017">6.51967</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0018">950.368</td></tr><tr><th class="align-left valign-top" id="en0019" scope="row"><strong>Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H</strong></th><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0020">Alluaudite</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0021">12.64599</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0022">12.76850</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0023">6.51697</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0024">949.206</td></tr><tr><th class="align-left valign-top" id="en0025" scope="row"><strong>Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C</strong></th><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0026">Alluaudite</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0027">12.67045</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0028">12.77769</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0029">6.52474</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0030">952.961</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0009">Both density functional theory (DFT) calculations and experimental results indicate that Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> readily converts to Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O in humid environments. This conversion subsequently leads to the formation of more Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities after a second calcination [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0028" name="bbib0028" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0028"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>]. This subtle transformation is observed by a decrease in the diffraction intensity of the main peaks (240) and (200), with the intensity ratio of I<sub>(240)</sub>: I<sub>(200)</sub> gradually dropping below 1.0 [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>]. As the hydration reaction progresses, the formation of additional Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities alters the δ value of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. The change in the Na/Fe ratio may increase the disorder within Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and reduce its crystallinity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0015" name="bbib0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>]. A comparable phenomenon, known as cation intermixing, is commonly observed in layered metal-oxide cathodes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0030" name="bbib0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0031" name="bbib0031" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0031"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a>]. In our study, the intensity ratios of I<sub>(240)</sub>: I<sub>(200)</sub> for Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H were determined to be 1.08 and 0.84, respectively, indicating a lower crystallinity of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H. Furthermore, Rietveld refinement analysis of X-ray diffraction (XRD) results estimate the mass fractions of Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities in the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H systems to be 15.3 wt.% and 17.7 wt.%, indicating a higher degree of structural disorder in Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H. Both Plewa et al. and Yang et al. demonstrate that the mixed precursors transform into Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> within the temperature range of 250–300 °C, as evidenced by in-situ high-temperature XRD tests [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0027" name="bbib0027" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0027"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>]. Thus, the presence of water vapor on the inner wall of the tube at 270 °C or higher significantly increases the risk of structural damage to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. In summary, employing an anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor is beneficial for enhancing the crystallinity of the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> product, reducing the formation of Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities, and mitigating the risk of structural damage. To elucidate the transition mechanism from the anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor to the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> product, we propose the following reaction pathways:<span class="display"><span id="eqn0001" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn
