K(L(G,H),F)}function f(G,F,aa,Z,k,H,I){G=K(G,K(K(q(F,aa,Z),k),I));return K(L(G,H),F)}function D(G,F,aa,Z,k,H,I){G=K(G,K(K(p(F,aa,Z),k),I));return K(L(G,H),F)}function t(G,F,aa,Z,k,H,I){G=K(G,K(K(n(F,aa,Z),k),I));return K(L(G,H),F)}function e(G){var Z;var F=G.length;var x=F+8;var k=(x-(x%64))/64;var I=(k+1)*16;var aa=Array(I-1);var d=0;var H=0;while(H<F){Z=(H-(H%4))/4;d=(H%4)*8;aa[Z]=(aa[Z]| (G.charCodeAt(H)<<d));H++}Z=(H-(H%4))/4;d=(H%4)*8;aa[Z]=aa[Z]|(128<<d);aa[I-2]=F<<3;aa[I-1]=F>>>29;return aa}function B(x){var k="",F="",G,d;for(d=0;d<=3;d++){G=(x>>>(d*8))&255;F="0"+G.toString(16);k=k+F.substr(F.length-2,2)}return k}function J(k){k=k.replace(/rn/g,"n");var d="";for(var F=0;F<k.length;F++){var x=k.charCodeAt(F);if(x<128){d+=String.fromCharCode(x)}else{if((x>127)&&(x<2048)){d+=String.fromCharCode((x>>6)|192);d+=String.fromCharCode((x&63)|128)}else{d+=String.fromCharCode((x>>12)|224);d+=String.fromCharCode(((x>>6)&63)|128);d+=String.fromCharCode((x&63)|128)}}}return d}var C=Array();var P,h,E,v,g,Y,X,W,V;var S=7,Q=12,N=17,M=22;var A=5,z=9,y=14,w=20;var o=4,m=11,l=16,j=23;var U=6,T=10,R=15,O=21;s=J(s);C=e(s);Y=1732584193;X=4023233417;W=2562383102;V=271733878;for(P=0;P<C.length;P+=16){h=Y;E=X;v=W;g=V;Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+0],S,3614090360);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+1],Q,3905402710);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+2],N,606105819);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+3],M,3250441966);Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+4],S,4118548399);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+5],Q,1200080426);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+6],N,2821735955);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+7],M,4249261313);Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+8],S,1770035416);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+9],Q,2336552879);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+10],N,4294925233);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+11],M,2304563134);Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+12],S,1804603682);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+13],Q,4254626195);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+14],N,2792965006);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+15],M,1236535329);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+1],A,4129170786);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+6],z,3225465664);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+11],y,643717713);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+0],w,3921069994);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+5],A,3593408605);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+10],z,38016083);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+15],y,3634488961);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+4],w,3889429448);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+9],A,568446438);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+14],z,3275163606);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+3],y,4107603335);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+8],w,1163531501);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+13],A,2850285829);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+2],z,4243563512);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+7],y,1735328473);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+12],w,2368359562);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+5],o,4294588738);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+8],m,2272392833);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+11],l,1839030562);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+14],j,4259657740);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+1],o,2763975236);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+4],m,1272893353);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+7],l,4139469664);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+10],j,3200236656);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+13],o,681279174);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+0],m,3936430074);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+3],l,3572445317);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+6],j,76029189);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+9],o,3654602809);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+12],m,3873151461);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+15],l,530742520);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+2],j,3299628645);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+0],U,4096336452);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+7],T,1126891415);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+14],R,2878612391);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+5],O,4237533241);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+12],U,1700485571);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+3],T,2399980690);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+10],R,4293915773);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+1],O,2240044497);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+8],U,1873313359);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+15],T,4264355552);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+6],R,2734768916);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+13],O,1309151649);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+4],U,4149444226);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+11],T,3174756917);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+2],R,718787259);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+9],O,3951481745);Y=K(Y,h);X=K(X,E);W=K(W,v);V=K(V,g)}var i=B(Y)+B(X)+B(W)+B(V);return i.toLowerCase()}
    ,stripProductDelimiters: function(val) {
        if (val) {
            return val.replace(/\;|\||\,/gi, '-');
        }
    }

    ,setCookie: function(name, value, seconds, domain) {
        domain = document.location.hostname;
        var expires = '';
        var expiresNow = '';
        var date = new Date();
        date.setTime(date.getTime() + (-1 * 1000));
        expiresNow = "; expires=" + date.toGMTString();

        if (typeof(seconds) != 'undefined') {
            date.setTime(date.getTime() + (seconds * 1000));
            expires = '; expires=' + date.toGMTString();
        }

        var type = typeof(value);
        type = type.toLowerCase();
        if (type != 'undefined' && type != 'string') {
            value = JSON.stringify(value);
        }

        // fix scoping issues
        // keep writing the old cookie, but make it expire
        document.cookie = name + '=' + value + expiresNow + '; path=/';

        // now just set the right one
        document.cookie = name + '=' + value + expires + '; path=/; domain=' + domain;
    }

    ,getCookie: function(name) {
        name = name + '=';
        var carray = document.cookie.split(';'), value;

        for (var i=0; i<carray.length; i++) {
            var c = carray[i];
            while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
                c = c.substring(1, c.length);
            }
            if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
                value = c.substring(name.length, c.length);
                try {
                    value = JSON.parse(value);
                } catch(ex) {}

                return value;
            }
        }

        return null;
    }

    ,deleteCookie: function(name) {
        this.setCookie(name, '', -1);
        this.setCookie(name, '', -1, document.location.hostname);
    }

    ,mapAdobeVars: function(s) {

// async support fallback
(function(w) {
	var eventBuffer = [];
	if(w.appData) {
		if(Array.isArray(w.appData)) {
			eventBuffer = w.appData;
		} else {
			console.error('Elsevier DataLayer "window.appData" must be specified as array');
			return;
		}
    }

	w.appData = [];

	var oldPush = w.appData.push;

	var appDataPush = function() {
        oldPush.apply(w.appData, arguments);
        for(var i=0; i<arguments.length; i++) {
            var data = arguments[i];
            if(data.event) {
                if(data.event == 'pageLoad') {
                    w.pageDataTracker.trackPageLoad(data);
                } else {
                    w.pageDataTracker.trackEvent(data.event, data);
                }
            }
        }
	};

	w.appData.push = appDataPush;
	for(var i=0; i<eventBuffer.length; i++) {
	    var data = eventBuffer[i];
	    w.appData.push(data);
	}
})(window);

</script>
<script>_satellite["_runScript1"](function(event, target, Promise) {
_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: clearing tracking state");try{s.events="",s.linkTrackVars="",s.linkTrackEvents=""}catch(e){_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: s object - could not reset state.")}try{dispatcherData=JSON.parse(event.detail),window.ddqueue=window.ddqueue||[],window.ddqueue.push(dispatcherData),window.eventData=dispatcherData.eventData,window.pageData=dispatcherData.pageData,_satellite.track(dispatcherData.eventName)}catch(e){_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: exception"),_satellite.logger.log(e)}
});</script>

Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. u-h2 u-margin-s-ver"><span class="title-text">Transitioning from anhydrous Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> Precursor to Alluaudite-type class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ensm.2024.103925" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ensm.2024.103925</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="abs0001"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abss0001"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara009"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0001">A sol-gel synthetic route was developed to produce cost-effective Alluaudite-Type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes from anhydrous Stanfieldite-Type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor, avoiding potential damage from crystal water.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0002">The distinct physio-electrochemical properties of Stanfieldite-Type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Alluaudite-Type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> were elucidated through experimental analysis and DFT calculations.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0003">For all-climate condition tests at −25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite cathodes sustained over 90 % capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 c or exceeded 95 % after 200 cycles at 2 C.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="abs0002"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abss0002"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara010">Low-cost and long-life cathode materials, such as the polyanionic iron-based Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, are crucial for future large-scale energy storage applications. This material is typically synthesized from the hydrated precursor Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O. However, the vapor released during the heating of crystal water can lead to reduced crystallinity, increased fraction of Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities, and potential structural damage to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. For the first time, we synthesized a stable Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> material using a well-designed sol-gel method. This approach effectively mitigates the aforementioned risks by facilitating a unique transition from anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode. The enhanced crystallinity, controllable impurity fraction, and reduced migration barriers of the pristine Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode significantly improve electrochemical performance. Moreover, we constructed Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite cathodes to optimize their high-rate capacity and cycling retention. At 25 °C, these composites exhibit remarkable high-rate capacity and maintain an impressive 92.2 % capacity retention after 1000 cycles at 10 C. In tests under extreme conditions at −25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, they sustained over 90 % capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 C or exceeded 95 % after 200 cycles at 2 C. Furthermore, the assembled Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C//HC full cells demonstrate superior rate capacity and long-term cycling stability, indicating their promising potential for commercial applications.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="abs0003"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="abss0003"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara011"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0008"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-ga1.jpg" height="197" alt="Image, graphical abstract"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (260KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (260KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span>A sol-gel synthetic route was developed to produce cost-effective Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes from anhydrous Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor, avoiding potential damage from crystal water. The distinct physio-electrochemical properties of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> were elucidated through experimental analysis and DFT calculations. For all-climate condition tests at -25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite cathodes sustained over 90 % capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 C or exceeded 95 % after 200 cycles at 2 C.</div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829724007682"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829724007529"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="keys0001" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="key0001" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0002">Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub></span></div><div id="key0002" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0003">Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub></span></div><div id="key0001a" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0002a">All-climate condition</span></div><div id="key0003" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0004">Iron-based polyanion</span></div><div id="key0004" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0005">Sodium-ion batteries</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0006" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0005">The escalating environmental degradation attributed to conventional fossil fuels has underscored the imperative for investigating and cultivating sustainable, renewable, and clean energy alternatives [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0001" name="bbib0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a>]. Given the sporadic and disparate distribution of these renewable resources, the establishment of large-scale energy storage systems capable of judiciously harnessing and distributing energy emerges as a direct and efficacious solution [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0002" name="bbib0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a>]. Lithium-ion batteries, with their outstanding cycling life and moderate energy density, are widely adopted in industrial fields as large-scale energy storage containers [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0003" name="bbib0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>]. However, their subpar safety under high temperatures and poorer electrochemical performance at low temperatures are concerning [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0004" name="bbib0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0005" name="bbib0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>], especially in extreme application scenarios such as photovoltaic installations in deserts and wind power installations at high altitudes. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), with a similar energy storage mechanism to lithium-ion batteries, are viewed as potent contenders in the future large-scale energy storage market due to their earth-abundant elements, superior thermal safety and low-temperature electrochemical performance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0006" name="bbib0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">6</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0007" name="bbib0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">7</span></span></a>]. Consequently, the development of cost-effective, long-lasting cathodes for sodium-ion batteries that are suitable for large-scale energy storage applications in all-climate conditions, has captured researchers' attention. In this context, polyanionic iron-based cathode materials are recognized as one of the most promising candidates, attributed to their low cost, wide temperature stability and robust cycling performance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0008" name="bbib0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0009" name="bbib0009" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0009"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0010" name="bbib0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0006">Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> is recognized as an excellent cathode material due to its high operating voltage and moderate capacity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0011" name="bbib0011" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0011"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0012" name="bbib0012" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0012"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>]. However, its polyanionic framework leads to poor electronic conductivity and sluggish reaction kinetics [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0014" name="bbib0014" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0014"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0015" name="bbib0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>]. To mitigate the significant decomposition of SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> groups above 450 °C, researchers have employed both solid-state [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0016" name="bbib0016" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0016"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0017" name="bbib0017" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0017"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>] and aqueous-solution synthetic routes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0019" name="bbib0019" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0019"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>], incorporating ex-situ conductive materials with the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes to improve electrochemical performance. In aqueous-solution routes, the hydrated precursor Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O is typically used to produce Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0020" name="bbib0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>]. However, the vapor released from the heated crystal water may compromise the crystal integrity of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, potentially reverting it back to Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O through hydration reactions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>]. Additionally, the anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor cannot be directly obtained by sintering hydrated Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O material, leading to a product containing Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0022" name="bbib0022" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0022"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a>]. Some efforts have been made to synthesize the anhydrous precursor Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> by replicating the synthetic conditions used for Na<sub>2</sub>Co(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Na<sub>2</sub>Ni(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0023" name="bbib0023" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0023"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>]. Unfortunately, researchers have only succeeded in obtaining the stable Vanthoffite-type Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0023" name="bbib0023" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0023"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0025" name="bbib0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>]. Consequently, the physicochemical properties of a stable Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and the crystallographic transition mechanism from anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode have not yet been systematically reported.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0007">In this study, a stable Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> materials were synthesized for the first time. The potential risks of low crystallinity, structural damage, and irreversible formation of more Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities due to crystal water vapor were mitigated through the unique transition from anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor to Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode. Compared to electrochemically inactive Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, the pristine Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> exhibits enhanced low-rate capacity but demonstrates suboptimal performance in high-rate capacity and cycle retention. To address these limitations, we constructed the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite cathodes with improved conductivity, which exhibited a higher average working potential, superior high-rate capacity, and an excellent capacity retention. In tests under various climatic conditions at −25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, the composite cathodes maintained over 90 % capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 C or over 95 % after 200 cycles at 2 C. Furthermore, the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C//HC full cells, which were assembled with hard carbon (HC) as the anode and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C as the cathode, exhibited exceptional rate capacity and enhanced cycling stability.</div></section><section id="sec0002"><h2 id="cesectitle0007" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0008"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>a</strong> illustrates our carefully designed sol-gel synthesis pathway, specifically aimed at mitigating the deleterious effects of moisture on the Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, thus marking a significant departure from the traditional direct sintering methods. For comparison, we prepared the conventional hydrated Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O precursor and tried to obtain the related product Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H through a one-step calcination process (<strong>Figure S1</strong>). Notably, we observed that water droplets, which condensed from the water vapor, continued to form on the inner surface of the tube wall even as the temperature rose to approximately 270 °C during calcination (<strong>Figure S2</strong>). X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis delineates the distinct crystal structures of the Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>​Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>​)<sub>2</sub>​ and the Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. Comprehensive powder XRD Rietveld refinement data confirm that the crystal structure of the Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> phase is analogous to that of Na<sub>2</sub>Co(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (PDF#97–019–4629) and Na<sub>2</sub>Ni(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (PDF#97–019–4630) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0026" name="bbib0026" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0026"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>], while diverging from the derived phases Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H, and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 1</span></span></a><strong>b</strong>-<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a><strong>c, Figures S3-S4</strong>)[<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0027" name="bbib0027" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0027"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>]. A juxtaposition of the principal crystallographic data for Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H, and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C is delineated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl0001" name="btbl0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a> and <strong>Tables S1-S5.</strong> The Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> exhibits larger lattice parameters with <em>a</em> = 23.37554 Å, <em>c</em> = 17.46092 Å, and <em>V</em> = 4155.171 Å<sup>3</sup> compared to pristine Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. However, it has smaller lattice parameters of <em>b</em> = 10.31535 Å Notably, all principal crystallographic parameters of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H are smaller than those of pristine Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and modified Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C, indicating potential structural damage (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl0001" name="btbl0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a>).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0001"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr1.jpg" height="997" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0001"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0001"><p id="spara001"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. <strong>Synthetic routes and crystallographic structure of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>:</strong> (<strong>a</strong>) Schematic diagram of synthetic routes. (<strong>b</strong>) Powder XRD Rietveld refinement pattern of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>. The experimental profiles, calculated data, the difference, and the theoretical Bragg positions are represented by black circles, blue lines, orange lines, and solid ticks, respectively. (<strong>c</strong>) The crystallographic structure of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> is projected along the [100] direction, (<strong>d</strong>) the [010] direction, (<strong>e</strong>) the [001] direction, (<strong>f</strong>) three crystallographic site of Fe sites, and (<strong>g</strong>) local environment of seven independent Na sites. Gold spheres, yellow tetrahedra, and green octahedra represent Na<sup>+</sup>, SO<sub>4</sub>, and FeO<sub>6</sub>, respectively. One FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedron shares an edge with one adjacent SO<sub>4</sub> tetrahedron to constitute a FeSO<sub>8</sub> dimer. (<strong>h</strong>) Powder XRD Rietveld refinement pattern of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. The experimental profiles, calculated data, the difference, and the theoretical Bragg positions are represented by black circles, red lines, orange lines, and solid ticks, respectively. (<strong>i</strong>) The crystallographic structure of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> is projected along the [100] direction, (<strong>j</strong>) the [010] direction, (<strong>k</strong>) the [001] direction, (<strong>l</strong>) local environment of Fe sites, and (<strong>m</strong>) three independent Na sites. Green octahedra, yellow tetrahedra, and gold spheres represent FeO<sub>6</sub>, SO<sub>4</sub>, and Na, respectively. One FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedron shares an edge with another adjacent FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedron to constitute a Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>10</sub> dimer.</p></span></span></figure><div class="tables rowsep-0 colsep-0 frame-topbot" id="tbl0001"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0002"><p id="spara008"><span class="label">Table 1</span>. The principal crystallographic data for Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub>,</sub> Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H, and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="rowsep-1"><td scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0001"><span class="screen-reader-only">Empty Cell</span></td><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0002">Structure</th><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0003">a<br>(Å)</th><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0004">b<br>(Å)</th><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0005">c<br>(Å)</th><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0006">V<br>Å[<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0003" name="bbib0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>]</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><th class="align-left valign-top" id="en0007" scope="row"><strong>Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub></strong></th><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0008">Stanfieldite</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0009">23.37554</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0010">10.31535</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0011">17.46092</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0012">4155.171</td></tr><tr><th class="align-left valign-top" id="en0013" scope="row"><strong>Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub></strong></th><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0014">Alluaudite</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0015">12.65514</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0016">12.77267</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0017">6.51967</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0018">950.368</td></tr><tr><th class="align-left valign-top" id="en0019" scope="row"><strong>Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H</strong></th><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0020">Alluaudite</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0021">12.64599</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0022">12.76850</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0023">6.51697</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0024">949.206</td></tr><tr><th class="align-left valign-top" id="en0025" scope="row"><strong>Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C</strong></th><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0026">Alluaudite</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0027">12.67045</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0028">12.77769</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0029">6.52474</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0030">952.961</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0009">Both density functional theory (DFT) calculations and experimental results indicate that Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> readily converts to Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O in humid environments. This conversion subsequently leads to the formation of more Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities after a second calcination [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0028" name="bbib0028" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0028"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>]. This subtle transformation is observed by a decrease in the diffraction intensity of the main peaks (240) and (200), with the intensity ratio of I<sub>(240)</sub>: I<sub>(200)</sub> gradually dropping below 1.0 [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>]. As the hydration reaction progresses, the formation of additional Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities alters the δ value of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. The change in the Na/Fe ratio may increase the disorder within Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and reduce its crystallinity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0015" name="bbib0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>]. A comparable phenomenon, known as cation intermixing, is commonly observed in layered metal-oxide cathodes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0030" name="bbib0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0031" name="bbib0031" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0031"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a>]. In our study, the intensity ratios of I<sub>(240)</sub>: I<sub>(200)</sub> for Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H were determined to be 1.08 and 0.84, respectively, indicating a lower crystallinity of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H. Furthermore, Rietveld refinement analysis of X-ray diffraction (XRD) results estimate the mass fractions of Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities in the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H systems to be 15.3 wt.% and 17.7 wt.%, indicating a higher degree of structural disorder in Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H. Both Plewa et al. and Yang et al. demonstrate that the mixed precursors transform into Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> within the temperature range of 250–300 °C, as evidenced by in-situ high-temperature XRD tests [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0027" name="bbib0027" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0027"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>]. Thus, the presence of water vapor on the inner wall of the tube at 270 °C or higher significantly increases the risk of structural damage to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. In summary, employing an anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor is beneficial for enhancing the crystallinity of the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> product, reducing the formation of Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities, and mitigating the risk of structural damage. To elucidate the transition mechanism from the anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor to the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> product, we propose the following reaction pathways:<span class="display"><span id="eqn0001" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span is="true">2</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mn is="true">12.4362</mn><mspace width="0.28em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">o</mi><mi is="true">l</mi><mspace width="0.28em" is="true"></mspace><msub is="true"><mi is="true">H</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mi is="true">O</mi><mspace width="0.28em" is="true"></mspace></mrow></math></script></span></span></span><span class="display"><span id="eqn0002" class="formula"><span class="label">(2)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-2-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1.7766</mn><mspace width=&quot;0.28em&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>m</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>o</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>l</mi><mspace is=&quot;true&quot;>1.6383</mn></mrow></msub><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>(</mo><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>3</mn></msub><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>0.1383</mn><mspace width=&quot;0.28em&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>6</mn></msub><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>F</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>e</mi><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>(</mo><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>S</mi><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>O</mi><mn role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1.7766</mn><mspace width="0.28em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">o</mi><mi is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">S</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">O</mi><mn is="true">4</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="true"
