is="true"></mspace></mrow><mi is="true">N</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">a</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2.7234</mn></mrow></msub><mi is="true">F</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">e</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1.6383</mn></mrow></msub><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">S</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">O</mi><mn is="true">4</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">3</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mn is="true">0.1383</mn><mspace width="0.28em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">o</mi><mi is="true">l</mi><mspace width="0.28em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">N</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">a</mi><mn is="true">6</mn></msub><mi is="true">F</mi><mi is="true">e</mi><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">S</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">O</mi><mn is="true">4</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">4</mn></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-2"><math><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1.7766</mn><mspace width="0.28em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">o</mi><mi is="true">l</mi><mspace width="0.28em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">N</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">a</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mi is="true">F</mi><mi is="true">e</mi><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">S</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">O</mi><mn is="true">4</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mo is="true">→</mo><mn is="true">1</mn><mrow is="true"><mspace width="0.28em" is="true"></mspace><mtext is="true">mol</mtext><mspace width="0.28em" is="true"></mspace></mrow><mi is="true">N</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">a</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2.7234</mn></mrow></msub><mi is="true">F</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">e</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1.6383</mn></mrow></msub><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">S</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">O</mi><mn is="true">4</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">3</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mn is="true">0.1383</mn><mspace width="0.28em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">o</mi><mi is="true">l</mi><mspace width="0.28em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">N</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">a</mi><mn is="true">6</mn></msub><mi is="true">F</mi><mi is="true">e</mi><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">S</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">O</mi><mn is="true">4</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">4</mn></msub></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0010">The projected crystal structures of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> along various directions are illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>c</strong>-<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a><strong>e</strong>. To our knowledge, the authentic crystal structure of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> have not been previously reported in the literature. This structure incorporates a novel FeSO<sub>8</sub> dimer, establishing a framework similar to Mg<sub>3</sub>Ca<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0032" name="bbib0032" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0032"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0033" name="bbib0033" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0033"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a>]. All Fe<sup>2+</sup> ions have been allocated to Fe(1), Fe(2), and Fe(3) crystallographic sites, which are fully occupied (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>f</strong>). One FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedron share an edge with an adjacent SO<sub>4</sub> tetrahedral, thereby constituting a novel FeSO<sub>8</sub> dimer. The Na<sup>+</sup>ions are situated at seven distinct crystallographic sites, all fully occupied (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>g</strong>). For the Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, a markedly different projected crystal structure is presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>i</strong>-<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a><strong>k</strong>. All Fe<sup>2+</sup> ions were assigned to a singular Fe(1) crystallographic site [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>]. The partially occupied Fe<sup>2+</sup> ions reside in octahedra sites that share edges with adjacent FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedra, forming a renewed Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>10</sub> dimer (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>l</strong>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0034" name="bbib0034" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0034"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">34</span></span></a>]. The Na<sup>+</sup> ions occupy Na1, Na2, and Na3 crystallographic sites, with only Na1 sites being fully occupied (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>m</strong>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0035" name="bbib0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0011">Utilizing Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and High-Angle Annular Dark-Field Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (HAADF-STEM), we have elucidated the microstructure of the materials. The secondary particles of Na<sub>2</sub>​Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>​)<sub>2</sub>​ display an ant-nest-like morphology due to water loss during the vacuum drying process, with nanopores forming interconnected channels (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>a</strong>). The primary nanoparticles are separated into sizes ranging approximately from 100 to 200 nm. A distinctive amorphous carbon coating &lt;5 nm thick surrounds these nanoparticles, attributed to the antioxidant properties of ascorbic acid (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>b</strong>). The HAADF-STEM images and inverse Fourier-transform patterns reveal lattice fringe spacings of 4.10 Å and 5.73 Å, corresponding to the (402) and (112) planes of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>b, Figure S5</strong>). The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns confirm the polycrystalline nature of the Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> materials (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>c</strong>), aligning with diverse stripe shadow zones observed in HAADF-STEM images. Following calcination at 350 °C for 6 h, the ant-nest-like structure remains intact (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>e</strong>). A lattice fringe spacing of 2.40 Å is identified, pointing to the (112) plane of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>f, Figure S6</strong>). However, the SAED pattern indicates a single-crystal diffraction pattern (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>g</strong>). To our knowledge, single-crystal Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles may hold promise for battery applications, similar to single-crystal NCM811 cathodes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0036" name="bbib0036" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0036"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0037" name="bbib0037" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0037"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0038" name="bbib0038" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0038"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>]. As for the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C, the porous structure is retained, with exposed carbon nanotubes (CNTs) on the surface of secondary particles as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>i-j</strong>. The HAADF-STEM images confirm a lattice fringe spacing of 3.56 Å, corresponding to the (−131) plane of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>k, Figure S7)</strong>. These images further differentiate between Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> phase and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> phase, consistent with the distinct crystalline features revealed by XRD pattern. The STEM-EDS mapping results show uniform distribution of Na, Fe, S, and O elements across the three samples (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>d, h, l</strong>). The inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP) analysis has determined that the molar ratio of Na/Fe is consistently close to 2:1 for both fresh Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and calcined product (<strong>Table S6</strong>). This consistent Na/Fe molar ratio from the ICP experiments may have contributed to the previous misidentification of Na<sub>2</sub>​Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>​)<sub>2</sub>​ precursor as identical to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode​ in earlier studies [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0039" name="bbib0039" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0039"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0040" name="bbib0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0041" name="bbib0041" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0041"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0002"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr2.jpg" height="997" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0003"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (3MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (3MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0003"><p id="spara002"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <strong>Microstructure characterizations of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C:</strong> (<strong>a</strong>) Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) images of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> reveal a porous ant-nest-like structure of secondary particles surface. (<strong>b</strong>) High-Angle Annular Dark-Field Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>. The blue shadows, green shadows, red shadows, and purple shadows represent (402), (112) crystal plane of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> phase materials, respectively. (<strong>c</strong>) Selected Area Electron Diffraction (SAED) images of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>. (<strong>d</strong>) STEM-EDS mappings of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>. (<strong>e</strong>) SEM images of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. (<strong>f</strong>) HAADF-STEM images of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. The cyan shadows represent (112), crystal plane of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> phase. (<strong>g</strong>) SAED images of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. (<strong>h</strong>) STEM-EDS mappings of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. (<strong>i</strong>) SEM images of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C. (<strong>j</strong>) HAADF-STEM images of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C. The red shadows represent (−131) crystal plane of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C phase. (<strong>k</strong>) SAED images of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C. (<strong>l</strong>) STEM-EDS mappings of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0012">To enhance clarity and reliability of the results, the study focuses on elucidating the crystallization transition mechanism between Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> in the following sections. Initial thermogravimetric analysis (TG) reveals the crystallographic transition between these phases. Mass loss below 100 °C is attributed to the evaporation of interstitial water molecules, while significant mass loss above 450 °C is due to the decomposition of sulfate groups within the crystal lattice (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>a</strong>)[<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0042" name="bbib0042" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0042"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">42</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0043" name="bbib0043" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0043"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">43</span></span></a>]. The absence of gaseous by-products complicates the detection of slight mass changes in the 100–450 °C range using TG. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) overcomes this by highlighting the crystallographic transition, as shown by the blue-red double shadow region (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>a)</strong>. The transition from the nascent Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> phase to the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> phase occurred between 250 and 300 °C, followed by the decomposition of the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> phase above 400 °C. Ex-situ XRD patterns confirm the stability of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>​Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>​)<sub>2</sub> below 250 °C, with the emergence of Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>​ peaks at 300 °C (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>b</strong>). This study systematically verifies the new mechanism for transformation of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> to Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> post-sintering above 250 °C, different from previous assumptions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0039" name="bbib0039" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0039"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0040" name="bbib0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0041" name="bbib0041" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0041"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>]. Further physicochemical contrasts between Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> are made through Raman and FT-IR spectra, and XPS analysis. The Raman spectrum of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> shows only the G band due to the absence of post-sintering, with an I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> value of 0.98 for post-sintered Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>c</strong>). Organic elemental analysis identifies amorphous carbon content at 0.21 % for Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and 0.11 % for Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, respectively. FT-IR spectra reveal typical bending and stretching vibrations of SO<sub>4</sub> tetrahedral and Fe-O bonds, with a significant bathochromic shift in Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>d</strong>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>]. High-resolution XPS spectra show a larger occupied area for Na1 s in Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, attributed to multiple connections between seven distinct Na sites and adjacent ions (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>e</strong>). The Fe2p and S2p exhibited similar shape for Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, with minor intensity variations (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>f-g, Figure S8</strong>). For the O1 s and C1 s, a larger occupied area of C=O<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C was observed for Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, linked to non-carbonized antioxidant material (ascorbic acid) without sintering (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>h</strong>). Conversely, a larger occupied area of C=C/C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C in the C1s spectrum of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> is due to carbonized antioxidant material post-sintering (<strong>Figure S9</strong>).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0003"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr3.jpg" height="997" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0004"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0004"><p id="spara003"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. <strong>Physiochemical characterizations of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>:</strong> (<strong>a</strong>) Thermogravimetric-Differential Scanning Calorimetry (TG-DSC) curves and (<strong>b</strong>) Ex-situ powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) evolution patterns, with trace impurity Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> marked by ▼. (<strong>c</strong>) Raman curves, and (<strong>d</strong>) Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) curves, with red lines and blue lines representing Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, respectively. High-resolution X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of (<strong>e</strong>) Na1 s, (<strong>f</strong>) Fe2p, (<strong>g</strong>) S2p, and (<strong>h</strong>) O1 s.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0013">The band structure was analyzed to unveil the inherent conductivity from a quantum mechanics perspective, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>a</strong>-<strong>b</strong>. The band gap of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> measures at 3.570 eV, which is approximately 2.6 times wider than that of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. This indicates a higher energy requirement for electrons in Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> to hop into the conduction band, resulting in poor electronic conductivity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>]. Bond valence sum (BVS) calculations were utilized to identify accessible Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion pathways within the crystal lattice [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0044" name="bbib0044" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0044"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">44</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0045" name="bbib0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">45</span></span></a>]. The ΔBVS plots illustrate isosurfaces that delineate the space available for Na<sup>+</sup> migration, with maximum ΔBVS values below 0.4. Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> exhibits one-dimensional diffusion paths along the [001] direction [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0046" name="bbib0046" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0046"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">46</span></span></a>], while Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> features three-dimensional helical diffusion tunnels along the [101] direction, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>c</strong>-<strong>d</strong>. According to density functional theory (DFT) calculation, the migration energies for accessible channels in Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> specifically the Na2-Na2, Na3-Na3, and Na1-Na3 paths, are estimated to be 0.78, 0.68, and 0.45 eV, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>f)</strong> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0014" name="bbib0014" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0014"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>]. In contrast, the migration energies for Na<sup>+</sup> ions in Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> along the Na6-Na3 path, Na7-Na3 path, Na3-Na4 path, Na3-Na5 path, Na4-Na3 path, Na5-Na3 path, along Na3-Na6 path, Na3-Na7 path, Na2-Na7 path, Na2-Na6 path, Na6-Na7 path, and Na7-Na6 path are higher at 3.18, 2.20, 1.47, 2.63, 1.03, 1.90, 1.00, 1.64, 2.43, 1.54, and 1.30 eV, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>e)</strong>[<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0047" name="bbib0047" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0047"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. The practical reversibility of Na<sup>+</sup> (de)insertion in Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> might be impeded by these high migration barriers, despite the presence of three-dimensional helical Na<sup>+</sup> migration channels in the ΔBVS plots. In summary, we infer that Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> is unlikely to show satisfactory specific capacity unless it is converted to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0004"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr4.jpg" height="997" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0005"><p id="spara004"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. <strong>Sodium-ion diffusion kinetics of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>:</strong> (<strong>a, b</strong>) Band gap of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3,</sub>respectively. (<strong>c, d</strong>) Equi-value surface of the ∆BVS and the accessible Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion tunnel for Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, respectively. (<strong>e, f</strong>) The calculated Na<sup>+</sup> migration energy barriers along various paths within the crystal structures of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3,</sub>respectively.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0014">The electrochemical behavior of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> was systematically investigated. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><strong>a</strong> depicts the initial charge/discharge curves of the Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> at 1/20 C, with a voltage window of 2.0 to 4.5 V. Based on the Fe<sup>2+</sup>/Fe<sup>3+</sup> redox couple, the average voltage of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> cathode is approximately 3.5 V (vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>) at 1/20 C. The initial discharge capacity is recorded at 35 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup>, which corresponds to a mere 38.5 % of its single-electron theoretical capacity (ca. 91 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup>). The initial coulombic efficiency of 85 % might be attributed to potential electrolyte decomposition under the high cutoff voltage of 4.5 V [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0048" name="bbib0048" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0048"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>]. The D<sub>Q</sub>/D<sub>V</sub> curves reveal two pairs of reversible redox peaks at 3.59/2.87 V and 3.73/3.44 V, without similar irreversible peak change as reported in Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes during the initial and subsequent charging cycles [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>]. As the rate increases, 22 % of the theoretical capacity is available at 1/10 C, 13 % at 1/5 C, 5 % at 1/2 C, and close to 0 % above 1 C (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><strong>b</strong>). This rapidly fading of rate capacity may step from poor electronic conductivity and sluggish Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics. To further reveal underlying mechanisms of sluggish kinetics, the EIS, CV, and GITT analysis were conducted. The fitted resistances ohmic (Rs), cathode electrolyte interface (R<sub>CEI</sub>), and charge transfer (Rct) were determined to be 8.814 Ω, 143.7 Ω, and 684.2 Ω as detailed in Supplementary <strong>Table S7</strong>. The high R<sub>SEI</sub> and R<sub>ct</sub> are not conducive to rapid charge exchange and Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion. CV analysis shows an increase in peak current with scan rate escalation, while maintaining the integrity of the redox peak pairs. The reaction kinetics are calculated as follows [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0049" name="bbib0049" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0049"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>]::<span class="display"><span id="eqn0003" class="formula"><span width="16.226ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 6986 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(623,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1679,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4363,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5338,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-4"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr5.jpg" height="764" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="cap0006"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0006"><p id="spara005"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. <strong>Electrochemical performances of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> in half cells:</strong> (<strong>a</strong>) Charge-discharge curves of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, ranging from 2 V to 4.5 V at 1/20 C. The initial cycle is represented by a dashed red line, and the 2nd–10th cycles are represented by solid black lines. The inset reveals the D<sub>Q</sub>/D<sub>V</sub> curves of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor, exhibiting two pairs of redox peaks. (<strong>b</strong>) The rate capability is assessed from 1/20 C to 2 C, with an inset displaying select discharge profiles post charging to 4.5 V. (<strong>c</strong>) Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>. The inset provides an expanded view of the EIS spectra in the high-frequency domain alongside the corresponding equivalent circuit model. (<strong>d</strong>) Cyclic voltametric curves. The inset shows the logarithmic relationship between peak current density and scan rate during both charge and discharge process. (<strong>e</strong>) Long-term cycling stability of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> up to 100 cycles at 1/20 C.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0015">The constants <em>b</em> in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#eqn0003" name="beqn0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="eqn0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Eq. (3)</span></span></a>, with values of 0.5975 and 0.4391, approximate to 0.5, signifying diffusion-controlled kinetics during both charge and discharge processes (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><strong>d</strong>)[<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0050" name="bbib0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]. The contributions from capacitive and diffusion-controlled processes were further delineated according to <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#eqn0004" name="beqn0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="eqn0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Eq. (4)</span></span></a>. Notably, the capacitive contribution escalates from 8 % to 20 % as the scan rate increases from 0.1 to 0.5 mV <em>s</em><sup>−1</sup> during discharge (<strong>Figure S10</strong>). Surface capacitive effects typically enhance reaction kinetics[<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0051" name="bbib0051" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0051"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0052" name="bbib0052" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0052"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0053" name="bbib0053" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0053"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>]. During the charging process, the effective Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion efficient was is determined within a narrow voltage window of 3.3∼3.7 V as shown in <strong>Figure S11a</strong>. For the discharging process, the effective Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion efficient spans a broader voltage range of 3.6–2.45 V, with the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion efficient below 1.2 × 10<sup>−10</sup> cm<sup>2</sup>s<sup>−1</sup> (<strong>Figure S11b)</strong>. GITT results indicate that insufficient and sluggish Na<sup>+</sup> extraction at a narrow window may obstruct Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion during the charging process, culminating in a capacity significantly below the theoretical 91 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><strong>e</strong> portrays a poor capacity retention below 40 %, with a discharge capacity of only 13.26 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> after 100 cycles, albeit maintaining a coulombic efficiency near 100 %.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0016"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><strong>a</strong> shows the initial two cycles charge-discharge curves for both Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C cathodes. Notably, the first cycle demonstrates a distinct profile compared to the subsequent cycle, attributed to the irreversible migration of Fe<sup>3+</sup> to sodium vacancies [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0054" name="bbib0054" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0054"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">54</span></span></a>]. The pristine Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> exhibited a discharging specific capacity of about 66.34 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> with an average voltage of 3.70 V at 1/20 C, while the modified Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C cathodes exhibited a superior discharging specific capacity of 82 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> and a higher average voltage of 3.75 V. The cyclic voltametric (CV) analysis also corroborates the irreversible alteration in redox peak count between the initial and second cycles (<strong>Figure S12)</strong>. The Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion coefficients, as calculated from GITT curves, was between 1 × 10<sup>−11</sup> cm<sup>2</sup>s<sup>−1</sup> and 6 × 10<sup>−10</sup> cm<sup>2</sup>s<sup>−1</sup> for both Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C cathodes, however, the highest value of Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion efficient for Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C occur at higher voltage values due to the smaller polarization (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><strong>b, Figure S13</strong>). The EIS measurements confirmed the charge transfer resistance (R<sub>ct</sub>) for Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C cathodes were 890.4 Ω and 706.5 Ω, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><strong>c, Table S7)</strong>. The rate capacities for Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> were recorded at 50.3, 41.5, 32.7, 26.3, and 19.8 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> across the C-rates of 1/10 C, 1/5 C, 1/2 C,1 C and 2 C, respectively. The lower electron transfer resistance indicated that Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C may exhibit a superior rate capacity than Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><strong>d</strong>, the rate capacities of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C were recorded at 74.5, 69.5, 65.6, 63.0, and 60.6 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> across the C-rates of 1/10 C, 1/5 C, 1/2 C,1 C and 2 C, respectively. Moreover, the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C cathodes demonstrate remarkable stability during extended cycling tests, with a capacity retention of 92.3 % after 200 cycles at 1 C, 93.11 % after 500 cycles at 2 C and 92.2 % after 1000 cycles at 10 C.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0006"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr6.jpg" height="997" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="cap0007"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0007"><p id="spara006"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. <strong>Electrochemical performances of Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C cathodes in half cells:</strong> (<strong>a</strong>) Initial charge-discharge curves of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C cathodes between 2 V to 4.5 V at 1/20 C. The first cycle is represented by a dashed line, while the second cycle is represented by solid lines. (<strong>b</strong>) Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion efficient calculated from GITT curves. (<strong>c</strong>) Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS). Before the EIS spectra testing, all cells have performed 3 cycles at 1/10 C and charged to 4.5 V. (<strong>d</strong>) Rate capacity from 1/10 C to 2 C. (<strong>e</strong>) Cycling stability up to 200 cycles at 1 C. (<strong>f</strong>) Cycling stability up to 500 cycles at 2 C. (<strong>g</strong>) Long-term cycling performance up to 1000 cycles at 10 C.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0017">To evaluate the electrochemical robustness of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C cathodes under diverse climatic conditions, we conducted long-term cycling stability tests at −25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 7</span></span></a><strong>a</strong>-<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">7</span></span></a><strong>b</strong>. At a C-rate of 1 C, the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C cathodes exhibited specific capacities of 44.19 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> at −25 ℃, 57.9 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> at 0 °C, and 75 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> at 60 °C, respectively, and the capacity retention rates of all cathodes exceeded 90 % after 100 cycles. When the C-rate increased to 2 C, the specific capacities of the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C cathode was 30.7 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> at −25 °C, 54.4 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> at 0 °C, and 69.3 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> at 60 °C, respectively, and the capacity retention of all exceeded 95 % after 200 cycles. Subsequently, we assembled coin-type full cells using hard carbon (HC) as the anode and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C as cathode to evaluate the practical electrochemical performance of full cells at 30 °C. The Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C//HC full cells manifested an initial discharge specific capacity of approximately 70.87 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> at 0.1 C, along with an initial coulombic efficiency of 89.6 % (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a><strong>c)</strong>. The rate capability of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C//HC full cells was determined to be 69.29, 65.68, 62.40, 59.91, and 57.37 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 C rates, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a><strong>d)</strong>. Concluding the series of tests, the long-term cycling performance of the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C//HC full cells was scrutinized at 1 C and 2 C rates. The cells exhibited capacity retentions of 88.7 % at 1 C after 100 cycles and 83.1 % at 2 C after 200 cycles, underscoring their potential for deployment in high-performance sodium-ion batteries (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 7</span></span></a><strong>e-</strong><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">7</span></span></a><strong>f)</strong>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0007"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr7.jpg" height="742" alt="Fig. 7" aria-describedby="cap0008"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0008"><p id="spara007"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. <strong>Electrochemical performances under all-climate temperature condition:</strong> (<strong>a</strong>) Cycling stability of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C cathodes at 1 C at −25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, respectively. (<strong>b</strong>) Cycling stability of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C cathodes at 2 C at −25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, respectively. (<strong>c</strong>) Charge-discharge curves Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C//HC full cells at 1.5∼4.2 V at 1/10 C at 30 °C. (<strong>d</strong>) Rate capacity of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C//HC full cells at 30 °C, with an inset showcasing a light-emitting diode pattern powered by a coin-type full cell. (<strong>e</strong>) Cycling stability of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C//HC full cells up to 100 cycles at 1 C at 30 °C. (<strong>f</strong>) Cycling stability of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C//HC full cells up to 100 cycles at 2 C at 30 °C.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="sec0003"><h2 id="cesectitle0008" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0018">For the first time, we synthesized a stable Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> material using a well-designed sol-gel method. This approach mitigated potential risks associated with low crystallinity, structural damage, and the irreversible formation of Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities by facilitating a unique transition from the anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor to the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode. DFT calculations and experimental data corroborate the low inherent conductivity and sluggish kinetics of pristine Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> during sodiation/desodiation processes, which contributes to poor rate capacity and cycle retention. Benefiting from the improved conductivity, the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite cathode exhibited an average working potential of 3.75 V, an enhanced rate capacity of 60 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> at 2 C, and remarkable capacity retention of 92.3 % after 200 cycles at 1 C, 93.11 % after 500 cycles at 2 C and 92.2 % after 1000 cycles at 10 C. In all-climate condition tests at −25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, it also maintained excellent cycling stability, with capacity retention exceeding 90 % at 1 C after 100 cycles or over 95 % at 2 C after 200 cycles. Utilizing a commercial hard carbon anode, the assembled Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C//HC full cells demonstrated commendable rate capacity and sustained cycling stability. This work not only unveils a novel crystallization transition mechanism from the anhydrous Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor to the Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode, but also paves the way for developing cost-effective, all-climate Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite cathode for large-scale energy storage.</div></section><section id="sec0003a"><h2 id="cesectitle0008a" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0018a"><strong>Wei Yang:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Visualization, Validation, Software, Investigation, Data curation, Conceptualization. <strong>Qi Liu:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Validation, Supervision, Funding acquisition, Formal analysis, Conceptualization. <strong>Qiang Yang:</strong> Visualization, Validation, Formal analysis. <strong>Shijie Lu:</strong> Validation, Formal analysis. <strong>Wenxiu He:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision. <strong>Li Li:</strong> Supervision, Methodology, Formal analysis. <strong>Renjie Chen:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision, Methodology, Formal analysis, Conceptualization. <strong>Feng Wu:</strong> Supervision, Methodology, Formal analysis, Conceptualization.</div></section></div><section id="coi0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0010" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0021">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0009" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0020">This work was supported by the <span id="gs0001">National Natural Science Foundation of China</span> (Grant Nos. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52272187</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51902024</span></span></a>), the <span id="gs0002">Technology Innovation Center for Future Electrochemical Energy Storage System Integration</span> (Grant No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20220468125</span></span></a>), the <span id="gs0003">Natural Science Foundation of Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region of China</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2024ZD11</span></span></a>), the <span id="gs0004">National Postdoctoral Program for Innovative Talents of China</span> (Grant No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">BX20180038</span></span></a>). The authors extend their sincere gratitude for the financial support provided. Phys. Chem. 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (1)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1385894725033613"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Elucidating of moisture-induced degradation and rehealing of alluaudite Na&lt;inf&gt;2+2x&lt;/inf&gt;Fe&lt;inf&gt;2-x&lt;/inf&gt;(SO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; cathode for Sodium-Ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Chemical Engineering Journal</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Polyanion-type iron-based sulfates are promising candidates for cathode in sodium-ion batteries due to the cost-effectiveness. However, the material exhibits a high sensitivity to humidity, which significantly increases the costs associated with cell fabrication. Therefore, it’s critical for the industrial application to understand the humidity-induced degradation mechanism and develop regeneration strategies. In this study, Na<sub>2.67</sub>Fe<sub>1.67</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NFS) exhibiting an outstanding capacity retention of 77.8&nbsp;% after 6000 cycles, is used as the model to systematically investigate the intrinsic causes of degradation upon exposure to moisture. Specifically, water ingress and the strong Coulombic repulsion between Fe-Fe induce the decoupling of the [Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>10</sub>] dimer, causing the transformation into bloedite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O. The π-contributing orbital interaction between O of water and Fe, along with the hydrogen-bonding network formed between H in water and the lattice O, confers additional structural stability to the hydrate. Theoretical calculations and enthalpy measurements indicate that the hydration reaction is thermodynamically spontaneous, with the Gibbs free energy change of −0.91&nbsp;eV and the enthalpy change of –22.083&nbsp;kJ/mol. After two days of exposure to 50&nbsp;% humidity, the capacity degrades to approximately 83.5&nbsp;% and a secondary heating strategy is developed to restore the fully degraded NFS to its original crystal structure and recover up to 94&nbsp;% of the initial capacity. This study provides comprehensive insights into the causes of air instability in NFS and proposes an effective strategy for capacity regeneration.</div></div></div></div></li></ul></div></div></section></div><a class="anchor abstract-link anchor-primary" href="/science/article/abs/pii/S2405829724007517"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View Abstract</span></span></a><div class="Copyright"><span class="copyright-line">© 2024 Elsevier B.V. All rights are reserved, including those for text and data mining, AI training, and similar technologies.</span></div></article><div class="u-display-block-from-md col-lg-6 col-md-8 pad-right     (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>

          SVG: {
            scale: 90,
            linebreaks: { automatic: true }
          }
        });
      </script>
