class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="abs0001"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abss0001"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara009"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0001">A sol-gel synthetic route was developed to produce cost-effective Alluaudite-Type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes from anhydrous Stanfieldite-Type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor, avoiding potential damage from crystal water.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0002">The distinct physio-electrochemical properties of Stanfieldite-Type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Alluaudite-Type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> were elucidated through experimental analysis and DFT calculations.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0003">For all-climate condition tests at −25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite cathodes sustained over 90 % capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 c or exceeded 95 % after 200 cycles at 2 C.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="abs0002"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abss0002"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara010">Low-cost and long-life cathode materials, such as the polyanionic iron-based Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, are crucial for future large-scale energy storage applications. This material is typically synthesized from the hydrated precursor Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O. However, the vapor released during the heating of crystal water can lead to reduced crystallinity, increased fraction of Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities, and potential structural damage to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. For the first time, we synthesized a stable Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> material using a well-designed sol-gel method. This approach effectively mitigates the aforementioned risks by facilitating a unique transition from anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode. The enhanced crystallinity, controllable impurity fraction, and reduced migration barriers of the pristine Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode significantly improve electrochemical performance. Moreover, we constructed Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite cathodes to optimize their high-rate capacity and cycling retention. At 25 °C, these composites exhibit remarkable high-rate capacity and maintain an impressive 92.2 % capacity retention after 1000 cycles at 10 C. In tests under extreme conditions at −25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, they sustained over 90 % capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 C or exceeded 95 % after 200 cycles at 2 C. Furthermore, the assembled Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C//HC full cells demonstrate superior rate capacity and long-term cycling stability, indicating their promising potential for commercial applications.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="abs0003"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="abss0003"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara011"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0008"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-ga1.jpg" height="197" alt="Image, graphical abstract"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (260KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (260KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span>A sol-gel synthetic route was developed to produce cost-effective Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes from anhydrous Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor, avoiding potential damage from crystal water. The distinct physio-electrochemical properties of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> were elucidated through experimental analysis and DFT calculations. For all-climate condition tests at -25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite cathodes sustained over 90 % capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 C or exceeded 95 % after 200 cycles at 2 C.</div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829724007682"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829724007529"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="keys0001" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="key0001" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0002">Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub></span></div><div id="key0002" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0003">Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub></span></div><div id="key0001a" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0002a">All-climate condition</span></div><div id="key0003" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0004">Iron-based polyanion</span></div><div id="key0004" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0005">Sodium-ion batteries</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0006" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0005">The escalating environmental degradation attributed to conventional fossil fuels has underscored the imperative for investigating and cultivating sustainable, renewable, and clean energy alternatives [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0001" name="bbib0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a>]. Given the sporadic and disparate distribution of these renewable resources, the establishment of large-scale energy storage systems capable of judiciously harnessing and distributing energy emerges as a direct and efficacious solution [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0002" name="bbib0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a>]. Lithium-ion batteries, with their outstanding cycling life and moderate energy density, are widely adopted in industrial fields as large-scale energy storage containers [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0003" name="bbib0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>]. However, their subpar safety under high temperatures and poorer electrochemical performance at low temperatures are concerning [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0004" name="bbib0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0005" name="bbib0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>], especially in extreme application scenarios such as photovoltaic installations in deserts and wind power installations at high altitudes. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), with a similar energy storage mechanism to lithium-ion batteries, are viewed as potent contenders in the future large-scale energy storage market due to their earth-abundant elements, superior thermal safety and low-temperature electrochemical performance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0006" name="bbib0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">6</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0007" name="bbib0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">7</span></span></a>]. Consequently, the development of cost-effective, long-lasting cathodes for sodium-ion batteries that are suitable for large-scale energy storage applications in all-climate conditions, has captured researchers' attention. In this context, polyanionic iron-based cathode materials are recognized as one of the most promising candidates, attributed to their low cost, wide temperature stability and robust cycling performance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0008" name="bbib0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0009" name="bbib0009" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0009"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0010" name="bbib0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0006">Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> is recognized as an excellent cathode material due to its high operating voltage and moderate capacity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0011" name="bbib0011" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0011"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0012" name="bbib0012" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0012"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>]. However, its polyanionic framework leads to poor electronic conductivity and sluggish reaction kinetics [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0014" name="bbib0014" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0014"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0015" name="bbib0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>]. To mitigate the significant decomposition of SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> groups above 450 °C, researchers have employed both solid-state [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0016" name="bbib0016" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0016"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0017" name="bbib0017" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0017"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>] and aqueous-solution synthetic routes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0019" name="bbib0019" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0019"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>], incorporating ex-situ conductive materials with the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes to improve electrochemical performance. In aqueous-solution routes, the hydrated precursor Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O is typically used to produce Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0020" name="bbib0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>]. However, the vapor released from the heated crystal water may compromise the crystal integrity of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, potentially reverting it back to Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O through hydration reactions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>]. Additionally, the anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor cannot be directly obtained by sintering hydrated Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O material, leading to a product containing Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0022" name="bbib0022" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0022"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a>]. Some efforts have been made to synthesize the anhydrous precursor Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> by replicating the synthetic conditions used for Na<sub>2</sub>Co(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Na<sub>2</sub>Ni(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0023" name="bbib0023" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0023"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>]. Unfortunately, researchers have only succeeded in obtaining the stable Vanthoffite-type Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0023" name="bbib0023" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0023"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0025" name="bbib0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>]. Consequently, the physicochemical properties of a stable Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and the crystallographic transition mechanism from anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode have not yet been systematically reported.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0007">In this study, a stable Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> materials were synthesized for the first time. The potential risks of low crystallinity, structural damage, and irreversible formation of more Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities due to crystal water vapor were mitigated through the unique transition from anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor to Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode. Compared to electrochemically inactive Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, the pristine Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> exhibits enhanced low-rate capacity but demonstrates suboptimal performance in high-rate capacity and cycle retention. To address these limitations, we constructed the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composite cathodes with improved conductivity, which exhibited a higher average working potential, superior high-rate capacity, and an excellent capacity retention. In tests under various climatic conditions at −25 °C, 0 °C, and 60 °C, the composite cathodes maintained over 90 % capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 C or over 95 % after 200 cycles at 2 C. Furthermore, the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C//HC full cells, which were assembled with hard carbon (HC) as the anode and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C as the cathode, exhibited exceptional rate capacity and enhanced cycling stability.</div></section><section id="sec0002"><h2 id="cesectitle0007" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0008"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>a</strong> illustrates our carefully designed sol-gel synthesis pathway, specifically aimed at mitigating the deleterious effects of moisture on the Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, thus marking a significant departure from the traditional direct sintering methods. For comparison, we prepared the conventional hydrated Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O precursor and tried to obtain the related product Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H through a one-step calcination process (<strong>Figure S1</strong>). Notably, we observed that water droplets, which condensed from the water vapor, continued to form on the inner surface of the tube wall even as the temperature rose to approximately 270 °C during calcination (<strong>Figure S2</strong>). X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis delineates the distinct crystal structures of the Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>​Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>​)<sub>2</sub>​ and the Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. Comprehensive powder XRD Rietveld refinement data confirm that the crystal structure of the Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> phase is analogous to that of Na<sub>2</sub>Co(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (PDF#97–019–4629) and Na<sub>2</sub>Ni(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (PDF#97–019–4630) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0026" name="bbib0026" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0026"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>], while diverging from the derived phases Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H, and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 1</span></span></a><strong>b</strong>-<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a><strong>c, Figures S3-S4</strong>)[<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0027" name="bbib0027" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0027"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>]. A juxtaposition of the principal crystallographic data for Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H, and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C is delineated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl0001" name="btbl0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a> and <strong>Tables S1-S5.</strong> The Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> exhibits larger lattice parameters with <em>a</em> = 23.37554 Å, <em>c</em> = 17.46092 Å, and <em>V</em> = 4155.171 Å<sup>3</sup> compared to pristine Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. However, it has smaller lattice parameters of <em>b</em> = 10.31535 Å Notably, all principal crystallographic parameters of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H are smaller than those of pristine Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and modified Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C, indicating potential structural damage (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl0001" name="btbl0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a>).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0001"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr1.jpg" height="997" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0001"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0001"><p id="spara001"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. <strong>Synthetic routes and crystallographic structure of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>:</strong> (<strong>a</strong>) Schematic diagram of synthetic routes. (<strong>b</strong>) Powder XRD Rietveld refinement pattern of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>. The experimental profiles, calculated data, the difference, and the theoretical Bragg positions are represented by black circles, blue lines, orange lines, and solid ticks, respectively. (<strong>c</strong>) The crystallographic structure of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> is projected along the [100] direction, (<strong>d</strong>) the [010] direction, (<strong>e</strong>) the [001] direction, (<strong>f</strong>) three crystallographic site of Fe sites, and (<strong>g</strong>) local environment of seven independent Na sites. Gold spheres, yellow tetrahedra, and green octahedra represent Na<sup>+</sup>, SO<sub>4</sub>, and FeO<sub>6</sub>, respectively. One FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedron shares an edge with one adjacent SO<sub>4</sub> tetrahedron to constitute a FeSO<sub>8</sub> dimer. (<strong>h</strong>) Powder XRD Rietveld refinement pattern of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. The experimental profiles, calculated data, the difference, and the theoretical Bragg positions are represented by black circles, red lines, orange lines, and solid ticks, respectively. (<strong>i</strong>) The crystallographic structure of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> is projected along the [100] direction, (<strong>j</strong>) the [010] direction, (<strong>k</strong>) the [001] direction, (<strong>l</strong>) local environment of Fe sites, and (<strong>m</strong>) three independent Na sites. Green octahedra, yellow tetrahedra, and gold spheres represent FeO<sub>6</sub>, SO<sub>4</sub>, and Na, respectively. One FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedron shares an edge with another adjacent FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedron to constitute a Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>10</sub> dimer.</p></span></span></figure><div class="tables rowsep-0 colsep-0 frame-topbot" id="tbl0001"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0002"><p id="spara008"><span class="label">Table 1</span>. The principal crystallographic data for Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub>,</sub> Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H, and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="rowsep-1"><td scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0001"><span class="screen-reader-only">Empty Cell</span></td><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0002">Structure</th><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0003">a<br>(Å)</th><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0004">b<br>(Å)</th><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0005">c<br>(Å)</th><th scope="col" class="align-left valign-top" id="en0006">V<br>Å[<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0003" name="bbib0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>]</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><th class="align-left valign-top" id="en0007" scope="row"><strong>Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub></strong></th><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0008">Stanfieldite</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0009">23.37554</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0010">10.31535</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0011">17.46092</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0012">4155.171</td></tr><tr><th class="align-left valign-top" id="en0013" scope="row"><strong>Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub></strong></th><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0014">Alluaudite</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0015">12.65514</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0016">12.77267</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0017">6.51967</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0018">950.368</td></tr><tr><th class="align-left valign-top" id="en0019" scope="row"><strong>Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H</strong></th><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0020">Alluaudite</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0021">12.64599</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0022">12.76850</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0023">6.51697</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0024">949.206</td></tr><tr><th class="align-left valign-top" id="en0025" scope="row"><strong>Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C</strong></th><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0026">Alluaudite</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0027">12.67045</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0028">12.77769</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0029">6.52474</td><td class="align-left valign-top" id="en0030">952.961</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0009">Both density functional theory (DFT) calculations and experimental results indicate that Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> readily converts to Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O in humid environments. This conversion subsequently leads to the formation of more Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities after a second calcination [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0028" name="bbib0028" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0028"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>]. This subtle transformation is observed by a decrease in the diffraction intensity of the main peaks (240) and (200), with the intensity ratio of I<sub>(240)</sub>: I<sub>(200)</sub> gradually dropping below 1.0 [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>]. As the hydration reaction progresses, the formation of additional Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities alters the δ value of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. The change in the Na/Fe ratio may increase the disorder within Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and reduce its crystallinity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0015" name="bbib0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>]. A comparable phenomenon, known as cation intermixing, is commonly observed in layered metal-oxide cathodes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0030" name="bbib0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0031" name="bbib0031" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0031"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a>]. In our study, the intensity ratios of I<sub>(240)</sub>: I<sub>(200)</sub> for Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H were determined to be 1.08 and 0.84, respectively, indicating a lower crystallinity of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H. Furthermore, Rietveld refinement analysis of X-ray diffraction (XRD) results estimate the mass fractions of Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities in the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H systems to be 15.3 wt.% and 17.7 wt.%, indicating a higher degree of structural disorder in Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"></sub>H. Both Plewa et al. and Yang et al. demonstrate that the mixed precursors transform into Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> within the temperature range of 250–300 °C, as evidenced by in-situ high-temperature XRD tests [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0027" name="bbib0027" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0027"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>]. Thus, the presence of water vapor on the inner wall of the tube at 270 °C or higher significantly increases the risk of structural damage to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. In summary, employing an anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor is beneficial for enhancing the crystallinity of the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> product, reducing the formation of Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> impurities, and mitigating the risk of structural damage. To elucidate the transition mechanism from the anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> precursor to the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> product, we propose the following reaction pathways:<span class="display"><span id="eqn0001" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn id="para0010">The projected crystal structures of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> along various directions are illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>c</strong>-<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a><strong>e</strong>. To our knowledge, the authentic crystal structure of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> have not been previously reported in the literature. This structure incorporates a novel FeSO<sub>8</sub> dimer, establishing a framework similar to Mg<sub>3</sub>Ca<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0032" name="bbib0032" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0032"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0033" name="bbib0033" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0033"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a>]. All Fe<sup>2+</sup> ions have been allocated to Fe(1), Fe(2), and Fe(3) crystallographic sites, which are fully occupied (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>f</strong>). One FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedron share an edge with an adjacent SO<sub>4</sub> tetrahedral, thereby constituting a novel FeSO<sub>8</sub> dimer. The Na<sup>+</sup>ions are situated at seven distinct crystallographic sites, all fully occupied (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>g</strong>). For the Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, a markedly different projected crystal structure is presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>i</strong>-<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a><strong>k</strong>. All Fe<sup>2+</sup> ions were assigned to a singular Fe(1) crystallographic site [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>]. The partially occupied Fe<sup>2+</sup> ions reside in octahedra sites that share edges with adjacent FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedra, forming a renewed Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>10</sub> dimer (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>l</strong>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0034" name="bbib0034" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0034"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">34</span></span></a>]. The Na<sup>+</sup> ions occupy Na1, Na2, and Na3 crystallographic sites, with only Na1 sites being fully occupied (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>m</strong>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0035" name="bbib0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0011">Utilizing Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and High-Angle Annular Dark-Field Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (HAADF-STEM), we have elucidated the microstructure of the materials. The secondary particles of Na<sub>2</sub>​Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>​)<sub>2</sub>​ display an ant-nest-like morphology due to water loss during the vacuum drying process, with nanopores forming interconnected channels (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>a</strong>). The primary nanoparticles are separated into sizes ranging approximately from 100 to 200 nm. A distinctive amorphous carbon coating &lt;5 nm thick surrounds these nanoparticles, attributed to the antioxidant properties of ascorbic acid (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>b</strong>). The HAADF-STEM images and inverse Fourier-transform patterns reveal lattice fringe spacings of 4.10 Å and 5.73 Å, corresponding to the (402) and (112) planes of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>b, Figure S5</strong>). The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns confirm the polycrystalline nature of the Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> materials (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>c</strong>), aligning with diverse stripe shadow zones observed in HAADF-STEM images. Following calcination at 350 °C for 6 h, the ant-nest-like structure remains intact (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>e</strong>). A lattice fringe spacing of 2.40 Å is identified, pointing to the (112) plane of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>f, Figure S6</strong>). However, the SAED pattern indicates a single-crystal diffraction pattern (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>g</strong>). To our knowledge, single-crystal Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles may hold promise for battery applications, similar to single-crystal NCM811 cathodes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0036" name="bbib0036" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0036"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0037" name="bbib0037" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0037"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0038" name="bbib0038" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0038"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>]. As for the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C, the porous structure is retained, with exposed carbon nanotubes (CNTs) on the surface of secondary particles as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>i-j</strong>. The HAADF-STEM images confirm a lattice fringe spacing of 3.56 Å, corresponding to the (−131) plane of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>k, Figure S7)</strong>. These images further differentiate between Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> phase and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> phase, consistent with the distinct crystalline features revealed by XRD pattern. The STEM-EDS mapping results show uniform distribution of Na, Fe, S, and O elements across the three samples (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>d, h, l</strong>). The inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP) analysis has determined that the molar ratio of Na/Fe is consistently close to 2:1 for both fresh Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and calcined product (<strong>Table S6</strong>). This consistent Na/Fe molar ratio from the ICP experiments may have contributed to the previous misidentification of Na<sub>2</sub>​Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>​)<sub>2</sub>​ precursor as identical to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode​ in earlier studies [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0039" name="bbib0039" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0039"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0040" name="bbib0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0041" name="bbib0041" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0041"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0002"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr2.jpg" height="997" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0003"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (3MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (3MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0003"><p id="spara002"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <strong>Microstructure characterizations of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C:</strong> (<strong>a</strong>) Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) images of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> reveal a porous ant-nest-like structure of secondary particles surface. (<strong>b</strong>) High-Angle Annular Dark-Field Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>. The blue shadows, green shadows, red shadows, and purple shadows represent (402), (112) crystal plane of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> phase materials, respectively. (<strong>c</strong>) Selected Area Electron Diffraction (SAED) images of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>. (<strong>d</strong>) STEM-EDS mappings of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>. (<strong>e</strong>) SEM images of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. (<strong>f</strong>) HAADF-STEM images of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. The cyan shadows represent (112), crystal plane of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> phase. (<strong>g</strong>) SAED images of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. (<strong>h</strong>) STEM-EDS mappings of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. (<strong>i</strong>) SEM images of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C. (<strong>j</strong>) HAADF-STEM images of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C. The red shadows represent (−131) crystal plane of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C phase. (<strong>k</strong>) SAED images of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C. (<strong>l</strong>) STEM-EDS mappings of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0012">To enhance clarity and reliability of the results, the study focuses on elucidating the crystallization transition mechanism between Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> in the following sections. Initial thermogravimetric analysis (TG) reveals the crystallographic transition between these phases. Mass loss below 100 °C is attributed to the evaporation of interstitial water molecules, while significant mass loss above 450 °C is due to the decomposition of sulfate groups within the crystal lattice (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>a</strong>)[<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0042" name="bbib0042" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0042"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">42</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0043" name="bbib0043" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0043"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">43</span></span></a>]. The absence of gaseous by-products complicates the detection of slight mass changes in the 100–450 °C range using TG. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) overcomes this by highlighting the crystallographic transition, as shown by the blue-red double shadow region (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>a)</strong>. The transition from the nascent Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> phase to the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> phase occurred between 250 and 300 °C, followed by the decomposition of the Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> phase above 400 °C. Ex-situ XRD patterns confirm the stability of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>​Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>​)<sub>2</sub> below 250 °C, with the emergence of Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>​ peaks at 300 °C (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>b</strong>). This study systematically verifies the new mechanism for transformation of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> to Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> post-sintering above 250 °C, different from previous assumptions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0039" name="bbib0039" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0039"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0040" name="bbib0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0041" name="bbib0041" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0041"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>]. Further physicochemical contrasts between Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> are made through Raman and FT-IR spectra, and XPS analysis. The Raman spectrum of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> shows only the G band due to the absence of post-sintering, with an I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> value of 0.98 for post-sintered Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>c</strong>). Organic elemental analysis identifies amorphous carbon content at 0.21 % for Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and 0.11 % for Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, respectively. FT-IR spectra reveal typical bending and stretching vibrations of SO<sub>4</sub> tetrahedral and Fe-O bonds, with a significant bathochromic shift in Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>d</strong>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>]. High-resolution XPS spectra show a larger occupied area for Na1 s in Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, attributed to multiple connections between seven distinct Na sites and adjacent ions (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>e</strong>). The Fe2p and S2p exhibited similar shape for Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, with minor intensity variations (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>f-g, Figure S8</strong>). For the O1 s and C1 s, a larger occupied area of C=O<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C was observed for Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, linked to non-carbonized antioxidant material (ascorbic acid) without sintering (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>h</strong>). Conversely, a larger occupied area of C=C/C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C in the C1s spectrum of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> is due to carbonized antioxidant material post-sintering (<strong>Figure S9</strong>).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0003"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr3.jpg" height="997" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0004"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0004"><p id="spara003"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. <strong>Physiochemical characterizations of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>:</strong> (<strong>a</strong>) Thermogravimetric-Differential Scanning Calorimetry (TG-DSC) curves and (<strong>b</strong>) Ex-situ powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) evolution patterns, with trace impurity Na<sub>6</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> marked by ▼. (<strong>c</strong>) Raman curves, and (<strong>d</strong>) Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) curves, with red lines and blue lines representing Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, respectively. High-resolution X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of (<strong>e</strong>) Na1 s, (<strong>f</strong>) Fe2p, (<strong>g</strong>) S2p, and (<strong>h</strong>) O1 s.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0013">The band structure was analyzed to unveil the inherent conductivity from a quantum mechanics perspective, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>a</strong>-<strong>b</strong>. The band gap of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> measures at 3.570 eV, which is approximately 2.6 times wider than that of Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. This indicates a higher energy requirement for electrons in Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> to hop into the conduction band, resulting in poor electronic conductivity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>]. Bond valence sum (BVS) calculations were utilized to identify accessible Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion pathways within the crystal lattice [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0044" name="bbib0044" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0044"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">44</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0045" name="bbib0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">45</span></span></a>]. The ΔBVS plots illustrate isosurfaces that delineate the space available for Na<sup>+</sup> migration, with maximum ΔBVS values below 0.4. Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> exhibits one-dimensional diffusion paths along the [001] direction [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0046" name="bbib0046" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0046"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">46</span></span></a>], while Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> features three-dimensional helical diffusion tunnels along the [101] direction, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>c</strong>-<strong>d</strong>. According to density functional theory (DFT) calculation, the migration energies for accessible channels in Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> specifically the Na2-Na2, Na3-Na3, and Na1-Na3 paths, are estimated to be 0.78, 0.68, and 0.45 eV, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>f)</strong> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0014" name="bbib0014" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0014"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>]. In contrast, the migration energies for Na<sup>+</sup> ions in Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> along the Na6-Na3 path, Na7-Na3 path, Na3-Na4 path, Na3-Na5 path, Na4-Na3 path, Na5-Na3 path, along Na3-Na6 path, Na3-Na7 path, Na2-Na7 path, Na2-Na6 path, Na6-Na7 path, and Na7-Na6 path are higher at 3.18, 2.20, 1.47, 2.63, 1.03, 1.90, 1.00, 1.64, 2.43, 1.54, and 1.30 eV, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>e)</strong>[<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0047" name="bbib0047" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0047"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. The practical reversibility of Na<sup>+</sup> (de)insertion in Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> might be impeded by these high migration barriers, despite the presence of three-dimensional helical Na<sup>+</sup> migration channels in the ΔBVS plots. In summary, we infer that Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> is unlikely to show satisfactory specific capacity unless it is converted to Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0004"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr4.jpg" height="997" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724007517-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0005"><p id="spara004"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. <strong>Sodium-ion diffusion kinetics of Stanfieldite-type Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Alluaudite-type Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>:</strong> (<strong>a, b</strong>) Band gap of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3,</sub>respectively. (<strong>c, d</strong>) Equi-value surface of the ∆BVS and the accessible Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion tunnel for Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, respectively. (<strong>e, f</strong>) The calculated Na<sup>+</sup> migration energy barriers along various paths within the crystal structures of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> and Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3,</sub>respectively.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0014">The electrochemical behavior of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> was systematically investigated. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><strong>a</strong> depicts the initial charge/discharge curves of the Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> at 1/20 C, with a voltage window of 2.0 to 4.5 V. Based on the Fe<sup>2+</sup>/Fe<sup>3+</sup> redox couple, the average voltage of Na<sub>2</sub>Fe(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> cathode is approximately 3.5 V (vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>) at 1/20 C. The initial discharge capacity is recorded at 35 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup>, which corresponds to a mere 38.5 % of its single-electron theoretical capacity (ca. 91 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup>). The initial coulombic efficiency of 85 % might be attributed to potential electrolyte decomposition under the high cutoff voltage of 4.5 V [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0048" name="bbib0048" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0048"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>]. The D<sub>Q</sub>/D<sub>V</sub> curves reveal two pairs of reversible redox peaks at 3.59/2.87 V and 3.73/3.44 V, without similar irreversible peak change as reported in Na<sub>2+2δ</sub>Fe<sub>2-δ</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes during the initial and subsequent charging cycles [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>]. As the rate increases, 22 % of the theoretical capacity is available at 1/10 C, 13 % at 1/5 C, 5 % at 1/2 C, and close to 0 % above 1 C (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><strong>b</strong>). This rapidly fading of rate capacity may step from poor electronic conductivity and sluggish Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics. To further reveal underlying mechanisms of sluggish kinetics, the EIS, CV, and GITT analysis were conducted. The fitted resistances ohmic (Rs), cathode electrolyte interface (R<sub>CEI</sub>), and charge transfer (Rct) were determined to be 8.814 Ω, 143.7 Ω, and 684.2 Ω as detailed in Supplementary <strong>Table S7</strong>. The high R<sub>SEI</sub> and R<sub>ct</sub> are not conducive to rapid charge exchange and Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion. CV analysis shows an increase in peak current with scan rate escalation, while maintaining the integrity of the redox peak pairs. The reaction kinetics are calculated as follows [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0049" name="bbib0049" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(623,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn
